data.profileText: a Representative from Massachusetts; born in Dracut, Middlesex County, Mass., June 25, 1778; graduated from Harvard University in 1798; studied law; admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Haverhill, Mass., in 1802; elected as a Federalist to the Massachusetts state senate in 1811; moved to Lowell, Mass.; elected as an Adams candidate to the Nineteenth and to the succeeding Congress; elected as an Anti-Jacksonian candidate to the Twenty-first Congress (March 4, 1825-March 3, 1831); returned to Lowell, Mass., and later moved to Niles, Berrien County, Mich., where he died July 23, 1836; interment in Silverbrook Cemetery.

note.content: Elected to represent the Essex-North district.
Elected to represent the Essex-North district.
Elected to represent the Essex-North district.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Kaplan, Lawrence S. "Document: A New Englander Defends the War of 1812: Senator Varnum to Judge Thacher." Mid-America 46 (October 1964): 269-80.

researchRecord.name: In the Jeremy Robinson Papers, 1806-1832, approximately 1400 items.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include John Varnum. A finding aid is available in the repository.
